channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Gunmen Kill 10 Foreign Tourists in Northern Pakistan
item.description: Gunmen stormed a hotel in a remote part of northern Pakistan on Sunday and killed nine foreign tourists and a Pakistani guide near the foot of one of the world's tallest mountains, police and security officials said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: U.S. Petitions for Extradition in N.S.A. Case
item.description: The State Department asked Hong Kong to turn over Edward J. Snowden, which is likely to set off a tangled fight over his fate, legal experts said Saturday.
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY and SCOTT SHANE
item.media:description: A TV screen in Hong Kong with a news report about Edward J. Snowden, charged with espionage and said to be in the city.

item.title: Worst of Haze Shifts From Singapore to Malaysia
item.description: Malaysian authorities declared a state of emergency Sunday in a southern district where a smoky haze blamed on Indonesian forest fires has triggered one of the country's worst pollution levels in years.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Rare Case of Gun Violence in China Leaves 6 Dead
item.description: In a rare case of gun violence in China, a man fatally shot five people and beat a sixth to death, including some of his factory colleagues and a soldier, police said Sunday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: ‘Communist’ Is Still a Dirty Word in Vietnamese Immigrant Enclaves
item.description: Accusations of sympathizing with the Communists are fighting words in the Vietnamese American community, as a long drawn-out libel case in Washington State shows.
item.dc:creator: By KIRK JOHNSON
item.media:credit: Photographs by David Ryder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Duc Tan, left, filed a libel suit after he was accused of being a communist sympathizer by Norman Le, right.

item.title: Despite Assurances by Brazil’s President, Another Day of Demonstrations
item.description: Many dismissed President Dilma Rousseff’s proposals, which were short on details and included programs for which she has been unable to garner support.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN and SIMON ROMERO
item.media:description: Protesters march toward Mineirao stadium, before the start of the Confederations Cup soccer match in Belo Horizonte, Brazil.

item.title: Beijing Police Seek ‘Large and Vicious’ Suspects (With Wet Noses)
item.description: The prohibition has recently been enforced with zeal, alarming pet owners who thought the two-decade-old size restrictions had long since lapsed.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mother bought a puppy for her daughter at a legal dog market in Beijing. Large dog breeds, including collies, Dalmatians and Labradors, have long been banned from the city, and recently the government has stepped up a campaign to track down and remove the offending pets.

item.title: Martin Bernal, ‘Black Athena’ Scholar, Dies at 76
item.description: Mr. Bernal’s work ignited a debate by arguing that the African and Semitic lineage of Western civilization had been scrubbed from the record of ancient Greece by 18th- and 19th-century historians.
item.dc:creator: By PAUL VITELLO
item.media:description: Martin Bernal, who taught at Cornell for almost 30 years.

item.title: Bombers Hit 4 Iraqi Towns in the North
item.description: A suicide bombing inside a Shiite mosque during evening prayers and other attacks north of Baghdad killed 23 people in Iraq on Saturday, officials said.

item.title: Police Use Water Cannons on Istanbul Protesters
item.description: Demonstrators on side streets were also hit with tear gas, as antigovernment protests continued.
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU

item.title: Slurs Against Italy’s First Black National Official Spur Debate on Racism
item.description: Cécile Kyenge, Italy’s first black national official, has been bombarded with racial slurs and death threats during her first eight weeks in office.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The International Herald Tribune
item.media:description: Cécile Kyenge, 48, at her office in Rome last month. Ms. Kyenge, who is Congolese by birth, has been the minister of integration for eight weeks.

item.title: Following a Star, Kerry Applies Personal Touch
item.description: While his predecessor, Hillary Rodham Clinton, was a global celebrity, Secretary of State John Kerry is striving to carve out a legacy by taking on some of the world’s intractable problems.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry near Paris in May, where he met with Russia’s foreign minister to try to convene a conference aimed at ending the fighting in Syria.

item.title: Mexico Pursuing Vanished Victims of Its Drug Wars
item.description: In Nuevo León State, the authorities are doing the basic police work that is so often missing in this country, leaving countless crimes unsolved and unpunished.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD
item.media:credit: Kirsten Luce for The New York Times
item.media:description: Family members of people who have disappeared in Mexico displayed pictures of their loved ones this month in Monterrey.

item.title: Son and Heir? In Britain, Daughters Cry No Fair
item.description: Male-only inheritance has Britain looking at whether its aristocracy is an essential part of its identity, a quaint vestige of the past or a bit of both.
item.dc:creator: By SARAH LYALL
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Liza Campbell, daughter of the 25th Thane of Cawdor, says male-only inheritance is “essentially sexism in a privileged minority.”

item.title: Task Force Gives Insight on U.N. Nominee
item.description: When Samantha Power traded academia for a human rights post in the Obama administration in 2009, the question was how she would translate her moral outrage into policy.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: President Obama created the Atrocities Prevention Board at the urging of Samantha Power.

item.title: Human Rights Advocate Says He Was Beaten as Russian Officers Watched
item.description: Lev A. Ponomaryov said he was kicked and beaten during a forcible eviction that came amid mounting pressure on civil society groups that publicly criticize the government.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY

item.title: French Relish Cycle of Scandals Featuring Sarkozy-Era Officials
item.description: Nearly every week there are new revelations about the former president or his former top lieutenants, including Christine Lagarde, now the managing director of the International Monetary Fund.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: Former President Nicolas Sarkozy of France in Brussels in March.

item.title: Economic View: Emerging Markets, Hitting a Wall
item.description: As a result of various economic trends, developing nations may no longer be capable of sustained high-powered growth.
item.dc:creator: By TYLER COWEN
item.media:description: A protest in São Paulo, Brazil, last week over the nation’s economic course. Emerging markets may soon find it harder to sustain fast-paced growth.

item.title: 2 Executed by Hamas as Informers
item.description: The Hamas-run Interior Ministry in Gaza said that the two informants had been sentenced to death on charges of “spying for a hostile foreign party and attempted murder.”
item.dc:creator: By FARES AKRAM

item.title: Kerry, in Qatar, Warns Taliban While Also Building Support on Syria
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry warned that the newly opened Taliban office “has to be closed” if the insurgents do not respond to demands that they negotiate in good faith.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:credit: Tara Todras-Whitehill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry after a news conference in Doha, Qatar, on Saturday.

item.title: Flood Toll Reaches 1,000 in India as Thousands More Await Rescue
item.description: Most of the stranded were people on a pilgrimage known as Char Dham Yatra, which takes Hindus to four of the holiest shrines in Uttarakhand between May and November.
item.dc:creator: By BASHARAT PEER
item.media:description: A bridge to help people evacuate was damaged on Saturday in Govindghat, India.

item.title: India Ink: The New New Thing in U.S.-Indian Relations?
item.description: As U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry heads to India, many wonder if India’s relationship with America has failed to live up to its once lofty expectations.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By DANIEL KURTZ-PHELAN

item.title: The Lede: Brazil’s World Cup Winners Support Protests
item.description: Four former stars of Brazil’s national soccer team — Romário, Pelé, Ronaldo and Rivaldo — have expressed their support for the protest movement in recent days.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY and SERGIO PEÇANHA

item.title: India Ink: When the Himalayas Poured
item.description: A survivor tells his tale of survival and death as floods in northern India took the lives of hundreds of pilgrims.
item.dc:creator: By HARI KUMAR
item.media:description: A man pleaded with a soldier to allow him to board an army helicopter on Friday as the death toll from monsoon flooding in mountainous northern India reached nearly 600.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: J.W. Anderson and the Addictive Rush of Fashion
item.description: Suzy Menkes, the IHT’s fashion editor, talks to Jonathan (“J.W. Anderson”) Anderson at London Fashion Week about unisex styling, working with Donnatella Versace and the “addictive” rush of the industry today.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
